author: adiasg
content:
Weak Subjectivity in Eth2.0 - https://notes.ethereum.org/@adiasg/weak-subjectvity-eth2
This doc is aimed at informing client teams about weak subjectivity periods, how to calculate them, and what their implications are for clients.

I'm happy to explain more if something is unclear, or discuss general things about this topic.

author: arnetheduck
content: oh nice - I've been hoping for something like this! I'm curious - the doc argues that the validator set size should determine the safe WSP length - this seems complex - perhaps unnecessarily so - to educate on and to coordinate around

author: arnetheduck
content: what would the downside be to simply agree on a safety decay and use the 256k validator set size throughout? it seems to me that for smaller validator counts, the benefits of having a shorter WSP period are less useful, since everything is samller and easier anyway (state size for example)

author: adiasg
content:
Since the churn limit is constant at lower validator counts (specifically, 4 per epoch for <=2^18 validators), attackers are able to replace large parts of the validator set and produce conflicting attestations with a small (or even no) penalty.
Eg, if the validator set size is 400, it takes only 100 epochs to replace the validator set entirely.

author: djrtwo
content:
>  the doc argues that the validator set size should determine the safe WSP length -
the validator set size _does _ determine safe WSP length. The UX at low val counts can be tough here so if we compromise for UX (which might be reasonable), it would come at the cost of safety in certain types of attack scenarios

author: arnetheduck
content: well, but isn't a longer WSP period at least as safe as a shorter one, always?

author: adiasg
content: A longer weak subjectivity period allows for more churn in the validator set, and hence more power to the attacker

author: djrtwo
content: the longer ago your sync state is from, the more validators/balances can diverge on forks -- effectively reducing your accountable safety security margin (i.e. the amount of money that will be burned if someone creates two conflicting finalized histories)

author: adiasg
content:
The entire premise of WSP is this question, as mentioned in the doc: 
> An attacker takes control of the validator set at checkpoint C0. The attacker then finalizes conflicting checkpoints C1 and C2 for some future epoch. How far in the future should this epoch be at earliest, so that the attacker is slashed lesser than 1/3 - D fraction of the total validator set?

author: adiasg
content: If C1 and C2's epochs are further in the future, the attacker is slashed lesser

author: adiasg
content: At some critical point (corresponding to 33.3% safety decay), the attacker isn't slashed anything at all!
